bestBHT.bht: This young ruler, similar to the lawyer in Luke 10:25, believed that eternal life could be obtained through a singular act. Jesus's response to the young man's question will reveal if he was merely flattering Jesus or if he truly recognized that Jesus had the same authority as God.

Archibald T. Robertson: Precisely the same question is asked by the lawyer in Luke 10:25.
This young man probably thought that by some one act he could obtain eternal life.
The question of Jesus will show whether it was merely fulsome flattery on the part of the young man or whether he really put Jesus on a par with God.
John Gill: A young man, a ruler among the Jews, a civil magistrate, and a very rich man.
He ran after Jesus, and overtook him in the way, as he was going towards Jericho.
What shall I do to inherit eternal life?

bhtAttempts.bht: This young ruler, similar to the lawyer in Luke 10:25, believed that eternal life could be obtained through a singular act. Jesus's response to the young man's question will reveal if he was merely flattering Jesus or if he truly recognized that Jesus had the same authority as God.

Similar to the lawyer in Luke 10:25, a young ruler posed the question of what he must do to gain eternal life. This ruler, who was wealthy and held a position of authority among the Jews, approached Jesus and expressed his desire to obtain everlasting life with a single action. Jesus's response would determine if the young man's question was mere flattery or if he genuinely perceived Jesus as equal to God.

The young ruler, a wealthy and influential man among the Jews, approached Jesus with a question concerning his desire to inherit eternal life. This question mirrored that of the lawyer in Luke 10:25, suggesting that the young ruler believed in the possibility of obtaining everlasting life through a single action. Jesus's response to this query would serve as a test, revealing whether the young ruler's question was merely flattery or if he genuinely regarded Jesus as being on par with God.

The young ruler, a wealthy and influential man among the Jews, approached Jesus, seeking guidance on how to obtain eternal life. Just as the lawyer did in Luke 10:25, the young ruler believed that achieving this goal might be possible through a solitary act. Jesus's response would help determine if the young ruler's inquiry was mere flattery or if he genuinely perceived Jesus as possessing divine authority equivalent to God.

Seeking eternal life, a young ruler, esteemed among the Jews for his wealth and influence, approached Jesus with a question. His inquiry paralleled that of the lawyer mentioned in Luke 10:25, both suggesting the possibility of achieving everlasting life through a singular act. In response, Jesus would ascertain whether the ruler's question was motivated by mere flattery or if he truly acknowledged Jesus's divine standing on par with God.
